title: Game Theory – Nash Equilibrium
description: Understand mutual best responses and equilibrium stability (pure and mixed).

questions.question: (s_A*, s_B*) is a Nash equilibrium if:
options: u_A(s_A*, s_B*) ≥ u_A(s_A, s_B*) and u_B(s_A*, s_B*) ≥ u_B(s_A*, s_B) for all s_A, s_B
Both players achieve maximum possible payoff
questions.explanation: No unilateral deviation profitable → mutual best responses.

questions.question: Which game typically has two pure-strategy Nash equilibria?
At a Nash equilibrium:
options: No player can improve payoff by unilateral deviation
questions.explanation: That is the definition of NE.

questions.question: Nash equilibria need not be:
questions.explanation: NE can be inefficient (e.g., Prisoner’s Dilemma).

questions.question: In Matching Pennies, the equilibrium is:
A player’s best response is the strategy that:
options: Maximizes her utility given others’ strategies
questions.explanation: Best responses are conditional on others’ moves.

questions.question: If both players’ best responses intersect at (Row 2, Column 1), then:
questions.explanation: Intersection of best responses gives NE.

questions.question: Indifference condition in mixed equilibrium makes opponents:
options: Indifferent across actions they mix over
questions.explanation: Each player mixes to keep the other indifferent.

questions.question: Which is TRUE?
options: Some games lack pure NE but have mixed NE
questions.explanation: Existence in mixed strategies is guaranteed for finite games.
